# Flexor digitorum superficialis muscle

_Flexor digitorum superficialis_  
---

Details

[Artery](/wiki/Artery "Artery") | [ulnar artery](/wiki/Ulnar_artery "Ulnar artery")

[Antagonist](/wiki/Antagonist_\(muscle\) "Antagonist \(muscle\)") | [Extensor digitorum muscle](/wiki/Extensor_digitorum_muscle "Extensor digitorum muscle")

"d:Q847112")]  
  
**Flexor digitorum superficialis** (_flexor digitorum sublimis_) is an
extrinsic flexor [muscle](/wiki/Muscle "Muscle") of the [fingers](/wiki/Finger
"Finger") at the [proximal interphalangeal
joints](/wiki/Proximal_interphalangeal_joints "Proximal interphalangeal
joints").

It is in the [anterior compartment of the
forearm](/wiki/Anterior_compartment_of_the_forearm "Anterior compartment of
the forearm"). It is sometimes considered to be the deepest part of the
superficial layer of this compartment,[1][2] and sometimes considered to be a
distinct, "intermediate layer" of this compartment.[3] It is relatively common
for the Flexor digitorum superficialis to be missing from the little finger,
bilaterally and unilaterally, which can cause problems when diagnosing a
little finger injury.[4]

##
Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Flexor_digitorum_superficialis_muscle&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Structure")]

The muscle has two classically described heads - the humeroulnar and radial -
and it is between these heads that the [median nerve](/wiki/Median_nerve
"Median nerve") and [ulnar artery](/wiki/Ulnar_artery "Ulnar artery") pass.
The [ulnar collateral ligament of elbow
joint](/wiki/Ulnar_collateral_ligament_of_elbow_joint "Ulnar collateral
ligament of elbow joint") gives its origin to part of this muscle.

Four long [tendons](/wiki/Tendon "Tendon") come off this muscle near the wrist
and travel through the [carpal tunnel](/wiki/Carpal_tunnel "Carpal tunnel")
formed by the [flexor retinaculum](/wiki/Flexor_retinaculum_of_the_hand
"Flexor retinaculum of the hand"). These tendons, along with those of [flexor
digitorum profundus](/wiki/Flexor_digitorum_profundus "Flexor digitorum
profundus"), are enclosed by a common flexor sheath. The tendons attach to the
anterior margins on the bases of the [intermediate
phalanges](/wiki/Intermediate_phalanges "Intermediate phalanges") of the four
fingers. These tendons have a split (Camper's Chiasm) at the end of them
through which the tendons of flexor digitorum profundus pass.

###
Innervation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Flexor_digitorum_superficialis_muscle&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Innervation")]

The Flexor digitorium superficialis muscle is innervated by the [median
nerve](/wiki/Median_nerve "Median nerve") (C7, C8, T1).[5]

##
Function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Flexor_digitorum_superficialis_muscle&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Function")]

The primary function of flexor digitorum superficialis is flexion of the
middle phalanges of the fingers at the [proximal interphalangeal
joints](/wiki/Proximal_interphalangeal_joints "Proximal interphalangeal
joints"), however under continued action it also flexes the
[metacarpophalangeal joints](/wiki/Metacarpophalangeal_joints
"Metacarpophalangeal joints") and [wrist joint](/wiki/Wrist_joint "Wrist
joint").

To test flexor digitorum superficialis, one finger is flexed at the proximal
interphalangeal joint against resistance, while the remaining three fingers
are held fully extended (to inactivate flexor digitorum profundus).

qa.question: where does the flexor digitorum superficialis distally attach
qa.answer: ["The tendons attach to the anterior margins on the bases of the intermediate phalanges of the four fingers. These tendons have a split (Camper's Chiasm) at the end of them through which the tendons of flexor digitorum profundus pass."]
